p: The crude hexane and ethyl acetate extracts of the leaves of Crateva adansonii showed moderate anti-trypanosomal activity with a MIC of 12.5 μg/mL (Igoli et al., 2012). In a further study, purpurin-18 ethyl ester (58), an anthraquinone derivative, was isolated from the extracts of the leaves of the related species C. adansonii and displayed a MIC of 6.25 μM against T. brucei. Molecular docking studies of 58 with some trypanosomal proteins revealed glutathione synthetase as its most likely target, followed by sterol-14α-demethylase and riboflavin kinase, with riboflavin kinase showing highest affinity (Igoli et al., 2014), although these models need experimental verification.
